title: REVIEW: Stomp, Mayflower Theatre, Southampton
text:
0 comments 
IT’S done for drumming what Cirque du Soleil has for acrobatics. 
Stomp has been around for nearly a quarter of a century and has been seen by 15 million people worldwide. 
I’d been impressed by a taster during the televised closing ceremony for the London 2012 Olympics , but was still left wondering what kept audiences enthralled for nearly two hours and kept them coming back for more. 
After seeing the show, it’s easy to work out how Stomp has lasted the test of time, seeing off a host of copycats along the way. 
Take eight bright young things, supply them with a host of inanimate objects and watch spellbound as they make their very own junkyard orchestra. 
Nothing is denied the Stomp treatment – brooms, mops, match boxes, lighters, bins, giant tyres, trolleys and, yes, even the kitchen sink. You can even make sweet music with the pages of the Daily Echo it seems. 
The exhaustingly energetic performers brilliantly weave their rhythmic magic onto everyday items and their own bodies. 
The lack of any spoken word explains Stomp’s global appeal and, judging by last night’s audience of young families, teenagers and pensioners, it also transcends age barriers. 
Despite being a bona fide phenomenon, the show has managed to retain much of its original charm. It was first dreamed up by buskers and became a huge street theatre hit at the Edinburgh Fringe and off Broadway. 
There are genuine laugh out loud moments, particularly for the youngsters, who couldn’t get enough of the toilet humour and willy jokes. 
Audience participation is positively encouraged. In fact, the crowd were worked into such a frenzy as they played along with Southampton ’s own Stomp performer Phil Batchelor that they refused to leave, stomping their own feet on the floor until the crew reappeared for an encore. Share article 
After more bin lids were whacked in perfect harmony, the performers bowed in front of a well-received standing ovation. And, unlike the death-defying circus skills of required in that other global phenomenon, you can try all this again at home.
